channel.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
channel.description:
i wrote this for someone and thought it took 10 mins to write why not give it its own topic
Okay. i will try help you
you want to start off and make a hello world app right? so, first you want to declare your class name, lets say.. firstApp
[b]public class firstApp[/b]
its [b]public[/b] because we want to be able to access it, it can be also [b]private[/b] but we dont want it to be. its class (duh) because its java and firstApp is the name of the application we chose.
we now need to add our brackets [b]{
}[/b]
in this is where ALL the code for that class goes otherwise you get errors.
in those brackets put this
[b]public static void main(Sting args[]) {
}[/b] its public because we want to be able to access it, it can be [b]private[/b]. [b]static[/b] means that only one instance of a given variable exists for a class. [b]void[/b] means these methods don't return any values. and main as its the [b]main[/b] method in that class and the [b](String args[])[/b] .. you will learn how to use that later and once again[b] brackets [/b]have to be setup.
ok, now your class is perfectly setup, you can put things in the main method, lets say that we want to print "Hello Universe, The World is Smaller Then You!!"
so in the [b]main[/b] method (and in its brackets) put
[b]System.out.print("Hello Universe, The World is Smaller Then You!!");[/b]
now you can save it as [b]firstApp.java[/b].
now make a new text file
paste this into it:
[i]@echo off javac -cp . *.java pause[/i]
Save it as [b]Compile.bat[/b]
now make a new text file and paste this in:
[i]@echo off java -cp . firstApp pause[/i]
Save it as [b]run.bat[/b]
then first double click on [b]compile.bat[/b] and wait for it, then double click on [b]run.bat[/b]
if you get an error, make sure you have [b]JDK[/b] installed, just search on www.google.com for "JDK Download" if you still get errors look further down in this post
and wallaa you see "Hello Universe, The World is Smaller Then You!!"
so you say what next?
id suggest looking at doing math in java like this:
[b]int number1 = 1; int number2 = 2; int number3 = number1+number2; System.out.println(number1+" + "+number2+" = "+number3);[/b]
Note: your putting that in the main method.
int is integer which is a number, just have a play around!
ok, if your getting errors still, you have not have file extensions viewed so that your calling your files actually firstApp.java.java so read on from here
Thanks To Pwnd for this Tut:
[quote="Pwnd, post:23, topic:11332"][b]You'll see what the problem is after this:[/b] [IMG]http://img165.imageshack.us/img165/1094/1xm1.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://img165.imageshack.us/img165/3921/2sz1.jpg[/img]
Now Rename .java.java to .java[/quote]

item.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: @yezus yezus
item.description:
@yezus wrote:

lol this is my second post on this forum so im still pretty bad at java.
so i was wondering if i did this rigth.
The firstApp.java file

[code]public class firstApp
{
public static void main(String args[])
{
System.out.print(“Hello Universe, The World is Smaller Then You!!”);

 }
}[/code]

The compile.bat file:

@echo off javac -cp . *.java pause
And finnaly The run.bat file

@echo off java -cp . firstApp pause
i get this error when i start

Exeption in Thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: firstApp

so What did i do wrong?
Please help me

Read full topic

item.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x

@1337h4x wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:36, topic:11444”][quote author=1337h4x link=topic=17015.msg291932#msg291932 date=1160111810]
umm just right click a picture select rename and put in ipwn.txt?
[/quote]

You’ll save it as ipwn.txt.png or whatever the picture format is unless you have “Hide extentions for known file types” unselected. “file.extention” ALWAYS saves as the extention, regardless if you have filetypes shown or not.[/quote]
umm no it doesn’t.

Look, I chaged a .png file to a .txt and opened with notepad.

item.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

[quote=“Drunk On Java, post:20, topic:11444”] Thirdly, naming conventions suggest classnames are LikeThis, not likeThis.
Actually you are wrong. Most classes are likeThis such as eGUI firstAPP bigLol etc.[/quote]

Actually methods are like that. Classes should be LikeThis.

Read full topic

item.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“ada, post:42, topic:11444”][quote]ok, if your getting errors still, you have not have file extensions viewed so that your calling your files actually firstApp.java.java
so read on from here[/quote]

Actually you could save it as “fileName.java” with the quotes and the program will not add an extention.[/quote]

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:36, topic:11444”][quote author=1337h4x link=topic=17015.msg291932#msg291932 date=1160111810]
umm just right click a picture select rename and put in ipwn.txt?
[/quote]

You’ll save it as ipwn.txt.png or whatever the picture format is unless you have “Hide extentions for known file types” unselected. “file.extention” ALWAYS saves as the extention, regardless if you have filetypes shown or not.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

ok, if your getting errors still, you have not have file extensions viewed so that your calling your files actually firstApp.java.java so read on from here

Actually you could save it as “fileName.java” with the quotes and the program will not add an extention.

Read full topic

item.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

[quote=“Drunk On Java, post:20, topic:11444”] Thirdly, naming conventions suggest classnames are LikeThis, not likeThis.
Actually you are wrong. Most classes are likeThis such as eGUI firstAPP bigLol etc.[/quote]
You’re an idiot. Don’t speak, ever.

In theory, how you choose to code is up to you, but coding conventions makes ‘correct’ code. Makes it easier to read.
http://java.sun.com/docs/codeconv/html/CodeConventions.doc8.html

Read full topic

item.title: Beginnger: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: @Kryptizzler Kryptizzler
item.description:
@Kryptizzler wrote:

http://java.sun.com/docs/codeconv/html/CodeConvTOC.doc.html

Yea, it is coder’s choice but it’s probably better practice to follow a convention :p. It’s there so that everyone will follow (hopefully).

80% of the lifetime cost of a piece of software goes to maintenance. Hardly any software is maintained for its whole life by the original author. Code conventions improve the readability of the software, allowing engineers to understand new code more quickly and thoroughly. If you ship your source code as a product, you need to make sure it is as well packaged and clean as any other product you create.

Read full topic
